sen.j: 山科区（やましなく）は、京都市を構成する11区の一つ。
sen.e: Yamashina Ward is one of the 11 Wards that constitute Kyoto City.
Yamashina Ward is one of the 11 Wards that constitute Kyoto City.
Yamashina Ward is one of the eleven wards that constitute Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 京都市の東側にある山科盆地の北部と、周辺の山地を区の範囲としている。
sen.e: It covers the northern part of Yamashina Basin, which lies on the eastern part of Kyoto City, and its surrounding mountainous districts.
It covers the northern part of Yamashina Basin, which lies on the eastern part of Kyoto City, and its surrounding mountainous districts.
It covers the northern part of Yamashina Basin, which lies on the eastern part of Kyoto City, and its surrounding mountainous districts.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Outline
Outline
Summary

sen.j: 東山 (京都府)により京都盆地から、音羽山 (滋賀県・京都府)や醍醐山（笠取山）などにより近江盆地からは隔てられている。
sen.e: Higashiyama (Kyoto Prefecture) divides it from Kyoto Basin, and mountains such as Otowa-yama Mountain (Shiga Prefecture, Kyoto prefecture) and Daigo-san Mountain (Kasatori-yama Mountain) separate it from Omi Basin..

Higashiyama (Kyoto Prefecture) divides Yamashina from Kyoto Basin, and mountains such as Otowa-yama Mountain (Shiga Prefecture, Kyoto prefecture) and Daigo-san Mountain (Kasatori-yama Mountain) separate it from Omi Basin.
Mt. Higashi (Kyoto Prefecture) divides Yamashina from Kyoto Basin, and mountains such as Mt. Otowa (Shiga Prefecture, Kyoto prefecture) and Mt. Daigo (Mt. Kasatori) separate it from Omi Basin.

sen.j: 昔から京都と東国とを結ぶ交通の要衝であった。
sen.e: It has long been a key junction for transpiration between Kyoto and eastern regions of Japan.
It has long been a key junction for transportation between Kyoto and eastern regions of Japan.
It has long been a key junction for transportation between Kyoto and eastern regions of Japan.

sen.j: かつては滋賀県との境の農村だったが、現在は京都市街地や大阪市のベッドタウンとなり、他地域からの移入者も多い。
sen.e: Though Yamashina Ward was once a farm village that borders on Shiga Prefecture, it has become a commuter town for downtown Kyoto and Osaka City and are populated by many residents who moved in from other regions.

Though Yamashina Ward was once a farm village that bordered Shiga Prefecture, it has become a commuter town for downtown Kyoto and Osaka City and is populated by many residents who moved in from other regions.

Although Yamashina Ward was once a farm village that bordered Shiga Prefecture, it has become a commuter town for downtown Kyoto and Osaka City and is populated by many residents who moved in from other regions.

sen.j: 東側は滋賀県大津市との県境に接しており、大津との結び付きも強い。
sen.e: Its eastern part of the ward borders on Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture and has a close connection with it.
The eastern part of the ward borders on Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture which has a close connection with it.
The eastern part of the ward borders on Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture and has a close connection with it.

sen.j: また、南側は伏見区醍醐地区と接しており、山科区と同一の生活圏や経済圏を形成している。
sen.e: Its southern part borders on Fushimi Ward Daigo area, which shares the same life and economic zones with Yamashina Ward.
The southern part borders on the Fushimi Ward Daigo area, which shares the same life and economic zones with Yamashina Ward.
The southern part borders on the Fushimi Ward Daigo area, which shares the same life and economic zones with Yamashina Ward.

sen.j: 山科区と醍醐地区との繋がりは、伏見区中心部と醍醐地区の繋がりよりも深いと言われる。
sen.e: The relationship between Yamashina Ward and Daigo area is said to be deeper than that between the central Fushimi Ward and the Daigo area.
The relationship between Yamashina Ward and Daigo area is said to be deeper than that between the central Fushimi Ward and the Daigo area.
The relationship between Yamashina Ward and Daigo area is said to be deeper than that between the central Fushimi Ward and the Daigo area.

sen.j: 山科盆地
sen.e: Yamashina Basin
Yamashina Basin
Yamashina Basin

sen.j: 古代
sen.e: Ancient Times
Ancient Times
Ancient Times

sen.j: 山科周辺は古くから交通が盛んであり、東山を越える日ノ岡峠、大津宿へ抜ける逢坂関が東海道の要所として知られていた。
sen.e: There were a lot of traffic around Yamashina since ancient times and the Hinooka-toge mountain pass over Higashiyma and the Osaka no Seki checking station toward the Otsu-juku Station are known as a crossroads of the Tokaido.

Since ancient times Yamashina has always had a sizable amount of traffic, and the Hinooka-toge mountain pass over Higashiyma as well as the Osaka no Seki checking station toward the Otsu-juku Station are known as crossroads of the Tokaido.

Since ancient times Yamashina has always had a sizable amount of traffic, and the Hinooka-toge mountain pass over Mt.Higashi as well as the Osaka no Seki checking station toward the Otsu-juku Station are known as crossroads of the Tokaido Road.
sen.cmt: Mt. としました。Tokaido Roadとしました。

sen.j: 山科は東海道の街道町であり江戸時代には特に栄えた。
sen.e: Yamashina, a post town of the Tokaido, flourished in particular during the Edo era.
Yamashina, a post town of the Tokaido, flourished in particular during the Edo era.
Yamashina, a post town of the Tokaido, flourished in particular during the Edo period.

sen.j: また、逢坂から南へ抜ける奈良街道（奈良に都があった頃の北陸道）、東山を日ノ岡の南で越える渋谷街道（東国と六波羅探題を結んだ）や京都府道118号勧修寺今熊野線、大岩街道など数多くの街道があった。
sen.e: There were many roads that passed through the city: the Nara Kido Road that extended south from Osaka (the Hokurikudo Road when Nara was capital), the Shibuya Kaido Road that crossed Higashiyama south of Hinooka (linking eastern regions with Rokuhara Tandai (the Kamakura Shogun's Kyoto Agent)), present-day Kyoto Prefecture Road No. 118 Kanshuji Imagumano Line, and Oiwa Kaido Road.

There were many roads that passed through the city: the Nara Kido Road that extended south from Osaka (the Hokurikudo Road when Nara was capital), the Shibuya Kaido Road that crossed Higashiyama south of Hinooka (linking eastern regions with Rokuhara Tandai (the Kamakura Shogun's Kyoto Agent)), present-day Kyoto Prefecture Road No. 118 Kanshuji Imagumano Line, and Oiwa Kaido Road.

There were many roads that passed through the city: the Nara Kaido Road that extended south from Osaka (the Hokurikudo Road when Nara was capital), the Shibuya Kaido Road that crossed Mt. Higashi south of Hinooka (linking eastern regions with Rokuhara Tandai (the Kamakura Shogun's Kyoto Agent)), present-day the Kajuji Imagumano Line of Kyoto Prefectural Route 118, and Oiwa Kaido Road.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。Mt. Higashi, Kanshuji Imagumano Line of Kyoto Prefectural Route 118 とそれぞれ変更しました。"Kajuji Imagumano Line"→"the Kajuji Imagumano Line"に変更しました。

sen.j: 栗栖野の台地には縄文時代から人が住み弥生時代の大規模な集落跡も見つかっている。
sen.e: The ruin of a large scale settlement in the Yayoi Period was found in a plateau of Kurisuno, showing people had lived there since the Jomon Period.
Ruins of a large scale settlement in the Yayoi Period were found in a plateau of Kurisuno, showing people had lived there since the Jomon Period.
Ruins of a large scale settlement in the Yayoi period were found in a plateau of Kurisuno, showing people had lived there since the Jomon period.

sen.j: 特に旧石器時代 (日本)後期から室町時代にかけての遺跡が重なっている中臣遺跡は重要な遺跡である。
sen.e: Nakatomi ruin is most important because it has several sites for the period from the late Old Stone Age (Japan) through the Muromachi Period.
Nakatomi ruin is most important because it has several sites from the period during the late Old Stone Age (Japan) through the Muromachi Period.
Nakatomi ruin is most important because it has several sites from the period during the late Old Stone Age (Japan) through the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 山科は古代より政権との結びつきが深く、669年には中臣鎌足によって精舎（山階寺）が作られ、7世紀末には天智天皇陵などが作られた。
sen.e: Since ancient times Yamashina had a close relation with governments; a garden for monks (Yamashina-dera Temple) was founded by NAKATOMI no Kamatari in 669 and the Imperial mausoleum of Emperor Tenji was built in the late 7th century,

Since ancient times Yamashina has had a close relation with governments; a garden for monks (Yamashina-dera Temple) was founded by NAKATOMI no Kamatari in 669 and the Imperial mausoleum of Emperor Tenji was built in the late 7th century,

Since ancient times Yamashina has had a close relation with governments; a garden for monks (Yamashina-dera Temple) was founded by NAKATOMI no Kamatari in 669 and the Imperial mausoleum of Emperor Tenji (Tenchi) was built in the late seventh century.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 平安京や比叡山延暦寺の創建後、安祥寺 (京都市)（848年）・毘沙門堂・勧修寺（900年）・曼荼羅寺（後の随心院、991年）など多くの寺院が作られ、区外の山科川下流の醍醐・笠取山の山上・山麓には醍醐寺（874年）が創建されている。
sen.e: After Heian-kyo and Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple had been built, many temples such as Anshoji Temple (Kyoto City) (in 848), Bishamon-do, Kaju-ji Temple in (in 900), and Mandara-ji Temple (later Zuishin-in Temple, in 991), and Daigo-ji Temple (in 874) was founded on and at the base of a Diago and Kasatori mountains along the lower Yamashina River outside the ward.

After Heian-kyo and Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple had been built, many temples such as Anshoji Temple (Kyoto City) (in 848), Bishamon-do, Kaju-ji Temple in (in 900), and Mandara-ji Temple (later Zuishin-in Temple, in 991), and Daigo-ji Temple (in 874) were founded on and at the base of the Daigo and Kasatori mountains along the lower Yamashina River outside the ward.

After Heian-kyo and Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple had been built, many temples such as Ansho-ji Temple (Kyoto City) (in 848), Bishamon-do, Kaju-ji Temple (in 900), and Mandara-ji Temple (later Zuishin-in Temple, in 991) were built, and Daigo-ji Temple (in 874) were founded on and at the base of the Mt. Daigo and Mt. Kasatori along the lower Yamashina River outside the ward.
sen.cmt: Ansho-ji としました。Mt. としました。

sen.j: 室町時代から戦国時代まで
sen.e: From Muromachi Period to the age of civil war
From Muromachi Period to the age of civil war
From the Muromachi period to the Sengoku period (period of Warring States)
sen.cmt: periodを小文字にしました。"Muromachi period to Sengoku period"→"the Muromachi period to the Sengoku period"に変更しました。

sen.j: 中世には「山科荘」（やましなのしょう）という荘園があり、これを代々保持していた公家の一流は後に山科家と名乗っていたが、戦国時代_(日本)を代表する教養人として知られた山科言継の代の1548年に室町幕府によってこれを奪われている。
sen.e: During the Middle Ages there were Shoen, or a manor named "Yamasina no sho," which had been owned by a noble family for generations--later named Yamashina family--until the Government of Muromachi, Muromachi Bakufu in 1548 deprived it from Tokitsugu YAMASHINA known as a person of rich culture representing the age of civil war (Japan).

During the Middle Ages there were Shoen, or a manor named "Yamasina no sho," which had been owned by a noble family for generations--later named Yamashina family--until the Government of Muromachi, Muromachi Bakufu in 1548 deprived it from Tokitsugu YAMASHINA known as a richly cultured person representing the age of civil war (Japan).

During the Middle Ages there was a Shoen, or a manor named 'Yamashina no sho,' which had been owned by a noble family for generations, later named Yamashina family, but Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1548 deprived it from Tokitsugu YAMASHINA known as a richly cultured person representing the Sengoku period (Japan).

sen.j: 室町時代後期の1478年に蓮如によって山科本願寺が建てられ、長大な土塁に囲まれた寺院群と寺内町が山科盆地の大きな面積を占めるようになった。
sen.e: Since Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple was founded by Rennyo in 1478 during the Muromachi period, temples and their precinct towns surrounded by long earthwork started to occupy a large area of Yamashina Basin,

Since Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple was founded by Rennyo in 1478 during the Muromachi period, temples and their precinct towns surrounded by long earthworks started to occupy a large area of the Yamashina Basin.

Since Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple was founded by Rennyo in 1478 of the late Muromachi period, temples and their precinct towns surrounded by long earthworks started to occupy a large area of the Yamashina Basin.
sen.cmt: 室町時代後期 としました。

sen.j: しかし城郭都市のようになった本願寺の存在と門徒たちの勢いを恐れた細川晴元は、京都市内をほぼ勢力下に置いた日蓮宗徒らと結託して一向宗に打撃を加えようとした。
sen.e: However Harumoto HOSOKAWA, fearing the presence of Hongwan-ji Temple--as if had been a walled town--and strength of its followers, joined hands with the Nichiren sect, who held power over the entire Kyoto City, attempted to attack the Ikko-shu sect.

However Harumoto HOSOKAWA, fearing the presence of Hongwan-ji Temple--as if it had been a walled town--and strength of its followers, joined hands with the Nichiren sect, who held power over the entire Kyoto City, and attempted to attack the Ikko-shu sect.

However Harumoto HOSOKAWA, fearing the presence of Hongwan-ji Temple--as if it had been a walled town--and strength of its followers, joined hands with the Nichiren sect, who held power over the entire Kyoto City, and attempted to attack the Ikko-shu sect.

sen.j: 1532年の天文法華の乱では日蓮宗徒たちは山科本願寺を陥落させ焼き討ちした。
sen.e: In 1532, the Nichiren sect followers destroyed and fired Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple in Tembun-hokke Rebellion.
In 1532, the Nichiren sect followers destroyed and burned Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple in the Tembun-hokke Rebellion.
In 1532, the Nichiren sect followers destroyed and burned Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple in the Tenbun-hokke Rebellion.

sen.j: この後本拠を失った本願寺勢力は大阪（石山本願寺）に移っている。
sen.e: The Hongwan-ji Temple sect lost its headquarters and moved out to Osaka (Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple).
The Hongwan-ji Temple sect lost its headquarters and moved to Osaka (Ishiyama Hongwanji Temple).
The Hongwan-ji Temple sect lost its headquarters and moved to Osaka (Ishiyama Hongwan-ji Temple).

sen.j: 山科本願寺は廃墟と化したが、今も高い土塁の跡が区内各地に残存している。
sen.e: Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple fell into ruins with only a high earthwork remaining in the Ward today.
Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple fell into ruins with only a high earthwork remaining in the Ward today.
Yamashina Hongwan-ji Temple fell into ruins with only a high earthwork remaining in the Ward today.

sen.j: 江戸時代
sen.e: Edo Period
Edo Period
Edo period

sen.j: 江戸時代は山科や四宮、そして髭茶屋追分（現在の大津市追分）までが東海道(三条通の開通に伴い、今は旧街道・旧三条通り等と呼ばれる)の街道筋として一続きの町となり、飛脚や参勤交代をはじめ多くの人々が行き交った。
sen.e: During the Edo Period, Yamashina, Shinomiya, and Higechaya-oiwake (present day Oiwake Otsu City) constitute a town along the Tokaido (it is now called Kyu-kaido after the opening the Sanjo-dori Street,), Old Kaido Road, or Old Sanjo-dori), where there were a lot of travelers including express messengers and parades of daimyo's alternating Edo residence.

During the Edo Period, Yamashina, Shinomiya, and Higechaya-oiwake (present day Oiwake Otsu City) constituted a town along the Tokaido (it is now called Kyu-kaido after the opening the Sanjo-dori Street, Old Kaido Road, or Old Sanjo-dori), where there were many travelers including express messengers and parades by daimyos who would alternate their Edo residence.

During the Edo period, Yamashina, Shinomiya, and Higechaya-oiwake (present day Oiwake, Otsu City) constituted a town along the Tokaido Road (it is now called Old Kaido Road or Old Sanjo-dori Street after the opening the Sanjo-dori Street), where there were many travelers including express messengers and parades by daimyos who would alternate their Edo residence.
sen.cmt: periodを小文字にしました。Tokaido Road としました。

sen.j: 髭茶屋追分からは京都を通らず大津宿と伏見宿、大坂を直接つなぐ伏見街道（大津街道）が山科盆地を南へ走っていた。
sen.e: The Fushimi Kaido Road (Otsu Kaido Road)--a route extending from Higechaya-oiwake and connecting the Otsu-juku Station and to Fushimi-juku Station and Osaka without passing through Kyoto--ran south of Yamashina Basin.

The Fushimi Kaido Road (Otsu Kaido Road)--a route extending from Higechaya-oiwake and connecting the Otsu-juku Station and Fushimi-juku Station as well as Osaka without passing through Kyoto--ran south of Yamashina Basin.

The Fushimi Kaido Road (Otsu Kaido Road)--a route extending from Higechaya-oiwake and connecting the Otsu-juku Station and Fushimi-juku Station as well as Osaka without passing through Kyoto--ran south of Yamashina Basin.

sen.j: また京都に住む天皇のため禁裏御料地として宮中に献上する作物を栽培したほか、近郊農村として京都の市民に野菜などを供給した。
sen.e: It also served as an Imperial estate for cultivating food to supply farm products to the Emperor living in Kyoto and as a suburban farmland to supply citizens of Kyoto City with vegetables.
It also served as an Imperial estate for cultivating food to supply farm products to the Emperor living in Kyoto and as a suburban farmland to supply citizens of Kyoto City with vegetables.
It also served as an Imperial estate for cultivating food to supply farm products to the Emperor living in Kyoto and as a suburban farmland to supply citizens of Kyoto City with vegetables.

sen.j: また大石内蔵助は山科区の西の端にあたる西野に住み、仇討ちまでの間、夜毎東山を越えて祇園に通いながら世間の目を欺いていた。
sen.e: Furthermore Kuranosuke OISHI had lived in Nishino, on the western edge of the Yamashina Ward, and kept everyone deceived by visiting Gion every day through Higashiyama until the revenge..

Furthermore Kuranosuke OISHI had lived in Nishino, on the western edge of the Yamashina Ward, and kept everyone deceived by visiting Gion every day through Higashiyama until he carried out his revenge.

Furthermore Kuranosuke OISHI had lived in Nishino, on the western edge of the Yamashina Ward, and kept everyone deceived by visiting Gion every day through Mt. Higashi until he carried out his revenge.

sen.j: 明治維新から第二次大戦まで
sen.e: From the Meiji Restoration to World War Two
From the Meiji Restoration to World War Two
From the Meiji Restoration to World War Two

sen.j: 明治以降、琵琶湖疏水や東海道本線、京阪京津線などが山科を通り、1933年に京津国道（後の国道1号、現在の三条通）が開通した。
sen.e: In and after the Meiji period, the Lake Biwa Canal, the Tokaido Main Line, and the Keihan Keishin Line were built in Yamashina, and the Keishin National Route (later the National Highway Route No.1 and now the Sanjo-dori Street) opened in 1933..
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In and after the Meiji period, the Lake Biwa Canal, the Tokaido Main Line, and the Keihan Keishin Line were built in Yamashina, and the Keishin National Route (later the National Highway Route No.1 and now the Sanjo-dori Street) opened in 1933..

In and after the Meiji period, the Lake Biwa Canal, the Tokaido Main Line, and the Keihan Keishin Line were built in Yamashina, and the Keishin National Route (later the National Route 1 and now the Sanjo-dori Street) opened in 1933..

sen.j: 大正から昭和にかけては繊維・染色関係の工場が建つなど、京都の郊外住宅・工業地として栄えた。
sen.e: In and after the Taisho and Showa period, it flourished as a residential suburb and industrial area after fibers and dyeing related plants were built.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In and after the Taisho and Showa period, it flourished as a residential suburb and industrial area after fibers and dyeing related plants were built.
In and after the Taisho and Showa periods, it flourished as a residential suburb and industrial area after fibers and dyeing related plants were built.

sen.j: 特に大きな工場は、1921年に西野にできた日本絹布であり、翌年鐘紡に吸収されその山科工場となった。
sen.e: In particular, a big plant of Nihon Kenpu, Nippon Kenpu, Japan Silk Cloth was built in Nishino in 1921 and became Kanebo Yamashina Plant in the subsequent year as the result of merger.
In particular, a big plant of Nihon Kenpu, Nippon Kenpu, Japan Silk Cloth was built in Nishino in 1921 and became Kanebo Yamashina Plant the next year as a result of a merger.
In particular, a big plant of Nihon (Nippon) Kenpu (Japan Silk Cloth) was built in Nishino in 1921 and became Kanebo Yamashina Plant the next year as a result of a merger.
sen.cmt: 英語名を括弧に入れました。

sen.j: 多くの女工が周囲に住み、近隣には市場や映画館もできるなど山科駅周辺の市街地化に貢献した。
sen.e: In the neighborhood, markets and movie theaters were built targeting many female workers who lived near the plant, contributing the urbanization of the area surrounding Yamashina Station.
In the neighborhood, markets and movie theaters were built targeting many female workers who lived near the plant, contributing to the urbanization of the area surrounding Yamashina Station.
In the neighborhood, markets and movie theaters were built targeting many female workers who lived near the plant, contributing to the urbanization of the area surrounding Yamashina Station.

sen.j: （山科工場は1970年に長浜に移転し、跡地は山科団地となっている。）
sen.e: (The Yamashina Plant was relocated to Nagahama in 1970 and Yamashina housing complex was built on the vacant site.)
(The Yamashina Plant was relocated to Nagahama in 1970 and Yamashina housing complex was built on the vacant site.)
(The Yamashina Plant was relocated to Nagahama in 1970 and Yamashina housing complex was built on the vacant site.)

sen.j: 又、京都郊外のレジャー地区としてゴルフ場、ダンスホール、料亭なども開設されている。
sen.e: Yamashina also developed as a leisure area in the suburb of Kyoto, as leisure facilities such as a golf course, a dance hall, and a high-class Japanese restaurant were built.
Yamashina also developed as a leisure area in the suburb of Kyoto, as leisure facilities such as a golf course, dance hall, and a high-class Japanese restaurant were built.
Yamashina also developed as a leisure area in the suburb of Kyoto, as leisure facilities such as a golf course, dance hall, and a high-class Japanese restaurant were built.

sen.j: 1931年に京都市東山区に編入されたが、この時点では住宅や工場は東海道沿いと山科駅周辺に集中しておりその他は竹やぶの散在する近郊農村だった。
sen.e: It was merged into Higashiyama Ward Kyoto City in 1931, when residences and plants were found only mainly along the Toakido and near Yamashina Station and most of the areas were suburban farmlands.

It was merged into Higashiyama Ward Kyoto City in 1931, when residences and plants were found only mainly along the Toakido and near Yamashina Station. The remaining areas were mostly suburban farmlands.

It was merged into Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City in 1931, when residences and plants were found only mainly along the Tokaido Road and near Yamashina Station; the remaining areas were mostly suburban farmlands.

sen.j: 第二次大戦後
sen.e: After World War Two
After World War Two
After World War Two

sen.j: 戦後は、名神高速道路の京都東インターチェンジや五条バイパス（現在の国道1号線）、区内の京都外環状線、敦賀市へ向かう湖西線が開通している。
sen.e: After the war constructed were the Kyoto Higashi Interchange of the Meishin Expressway, the Gojo By-pass, (present-day National Highway route No. 1), Kyoto Soto-Kanjo-sen Loop Line, and the Kosai Line leading to Tsuruga.

After the war, the Kyoto Higashi Interchange of the Meishin Expressway, the Gojo By-pass, (present-day National Highway route No. 1), Kyoto Soto-Kanjo-sen Loop Line, and the Kosai Line leading to Tsuruga, were constructed.

After the war, the Kyoto Higashi Interchange of the Meishin Expressway, the Gojo By-pass, (present-day National Route 1), Kyoto Outer Loop Expressway, and the Kosai Line leading to Tsuruga, were constructed.

sen.j: 高度経済成長以降は盆地内の農地の宅地化が進み、大型団地が建つなど京都や大阪のベッドタウンとなった。
sen.e: In and after the high-growth period, the farmlands were steadily turned into lands for housing in particular housing complexes, making it a commuter town for Kyoto and Osaka.
In and after the high-growth period, the farmlands were steadily turned into lands for housing in particular housing complexes, making it a commuter town for Kyoto and Osaka.
In and after the high-growth period, the farmlands were steadily turned into lands for housing, in particular housing complexes, making it a commuter town for Kyoto and Osaka.
sen.cmt: カンマを追加しました。

sen.j: ただし、この際に道路整備が追い付かなかった事が、区内各所での渋滞が慢性化している原因にもなっている。
sen.e: However, the development of roads did not catch up with the development of housing lands, which may cause chronic congestions of traffic in many areas within the ward today.
However, the development of roads did not catch up with the development of housing lands, which may be the cause of chronic traffic congestion in many areas within the ward today.
However, the development of roads did not catch up with the development of housing lands, which may be the cause of chronic traffic congestion in many areas within the ward today.

sen.j: 1976年（昭和51年）に東山区から分区され山科区となった。
sen.e: In 1976, Yamashina Ward was divided from Higashiyama Ward.
In 1976, Yamashina Ward was divided from Higashiyama Ward.
In 1976, Yamashina Ward was divided from Higashiyama Ward.

sen.j: 近年は湖西道路や、京都市中心部から日ノ岡の下を通り山科区を南に縦断する京都市営地下鉄東西線が開通するなど更なる交通網の整備が進んだ。
sen.e: In recent years, the traffic network has further improved with the development of the Kosai Road and the opening of Kyoto Municipal Subway Tozai Line which runs from central Kyoto, passes through the foot of Hinooka, and traverses Yamashina Ward southward.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In recent years, the traffic network has further improved with the development of the Kosai Road and the opening of Kyoto Municipal Subway Tozai Line which runs from central Kyoto, passes through the foot of Hinooka, and traverses Yamashina Ward southward.

In recent years, the traffic network has further improved with the development of the Kosai Road and the opening of Kyoto Municipal Subway Tozai Line which runs from central Kyoto, passes through the foot of Hinooka, and traverses Yamashina Ward southward.

sen.j: 山科駅駅前は地下鉄開通とともに再開発されデパート（大丸）が入る再開発ビルが建っている。
sen.e: With the opening of the subway, a building that houses a department store (Daimaru) was built in front of Yamashina Station in a redevelopment project.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: With the opening of the subway, a building housing a department store (Daimaru) was built in front of Yamashina Station for a redevelopment project.
With the opening of the subway, a building housing a department store (Daimaru) was built in front of Yamashina Station for a redevelopment project.

sen.j: そのため山科駅周辺ならびに地下鉄東西線が地下を走る外環状線沿線は活気ある街に育ちつつあるが、かつてのメインストリートであった旧東海道や京都府道117号小野山科停車場線の繁栄振りは鳴りを潜め、空洞化が進んでいる。
sen.e: This is why the surroundings of Yamashina Station and areas along the Outer Beltway have been developed into a lively town but, in contrast, areas along the Old Tokaido road and the Kyoto Prefecture Road No. 117 Ono Yamashina Teishajo Line were losing its prosperity and become hollowed out.

This is mainly the reason that areas surrounding Yamashina Station and areas along the Outer Beltway developed into a busy town but, in contrast, areas along the Old Tokaido road and the Kyoto Prefecture Road No. 117 Ono Yamashina Teishajo Line lost their prosperity.

This is mainly the reason that areas surrounding Yamashina Station and areas along the Outer Loop Expressway developed into a busy town but, in contrast, areas along the Old Tokaido Road and Ono Yamashina Teishajo Line of the Kyoto Prefecture Route 117 lost their prosperity.
sen.cmt: 外環状線→Outer Loop Expressway としました。

sen.j: 1889年（明治22年）4月1日 - 町村制施行に伴い、宇治郡山科村が成立。
sen.e: On April 1, 1889, Yamashina-mura Uji-gun were founded when the municipal organization was enforced.
On April 1, 1889, Yamashina-mura Uji-gun were founded when the municipal organization was enforced.
April 1, 1889: Yamashina-mura, Uji-gun was founded when the municipal organization was enforced.
sen.cmt: was としました。"On April 1, 1889, "→"April 1, 1889:"に変更しました。

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）10月16日 - 山科村が町制施行し山科町となる。
sen.e: On October 16, 1926,Yamashina-mura was organized as Yamashina-cho.
On October 16, 1926, Yamashina-mura was organized as Yamashina-cho.
October 16, 1926: Yamashina-mura was organized as Yamashina-cho.

sen.j: 1931年（昭和6年）4月1日 - 宇治郡山科町が京都市東山区に編入。
sen.e: On April 1, 1931, Yamashina-cho Uji District was merged into Kyoto City.
On April 1, 1931, Yamashina-cho Uji District was merged into Kyoto City.
April 1, 1931: Yamashina-cho, Uji District was merged into Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 東山区 を追加しました。"On April 1, 1931, "→"April 1, 1931:"に変更しました。

sen.j: 1951年（昭和26年）6月 - 東山区役所山科支所が発足。
sen.e: in June 1951, a ward office Yamashina Branch opened.

sen.j: 1976年（昭和51年）10月1日 - 東山区から分区され山科区となる。
sen.e: On October 1, 1976, Yamashina Ward was divided from Higashiyama Ward.
